file_metadata.authors: ["Junji Morokuma", "Douglas Blackiston", "Dany S. Adams", "Guiscard Seebohm", "Barry Trimmer", "Michael Levin"]
file_metadata.title: Modulation of potassium channel function confers a hyperproliferative invasive phenotype on embryonic stem cells

chunks.text: Ion transporters, voltage gradients, and electric fields play a role in embryonic development and regeneration, epigenetically regulating stem and tumor cell behavior. This study identifies a new function for KCNQ1, a potassium channel involved in human Romano-Ward and Jervell-Lange-Nielsen syndromes. Misexpression of its Î²-subunit KCNE1 in Xenopus embryos alters pigment cell lineage behavior in the neural crest. Depolarization caused by KCNE1 misexpression leads to melanocyte overproliferation, spreading, and invasion of blood vessels, liver, gut, and neural tube, resulting in hyperpigmentation. This effect is mediated by Sox10 and Slug gene up-regulation, linking ion channel function to migration, shape, and mitosis control during morphogenesis. These findings highlight KCNQ1's role in cell behavior regulation and reveal a biophysical switch conferring neoplastic-like properties on embryonic stem cells.
chunks.chunk_summary: KCNE1 misexpression in Xenopus embryos disrupts KCNQ1 function, leading to melanocyte hyperproliferation and invasion through Sox10 and Slug up-regulation.
chunks.authors: ["Junji Morokuma", "Douglas Blackiston", "Dany S. Adams", "Guiscard Seebohm", "Barry Trimmer", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Embryonic stem cell behavior is influenced by environmental signals, including ion currents, electric fields, and voltage gradients, which form a cellular communication system. Bioelectric signals are involved in cell migration, mitosis, differentiation, wound healing, limb development, left-right patterning, neurogenesis, tail regeneration, and cancer. Stem cells possess unique electrophysiological properties and express various electrogenic transporters. Membrane hyperpolarization is essential for myoblast differentiation, while electrical modulation can induce dedifferentiation, suggesting depolarization might promote a more primitive state. The role of electrical signals in stem cell morphogenesis and the transcriptional targets linking bioelectricity to cell behavior remain largely unknown. This study investigates ion flows regulating stem cell behavior during pattern formation, focusing on the KCNQ1/KCNE1 channel in neural crest regulation.
chunks.chunk_summary: Bioelectric signals, including ion flows and voltage gradients, play a crucial role in various developmental processes and stem cell behavior, but their specific mechanisms and downstream targets remain largely unexplored.
chunks.authors: ["Junji Morokuma", "Douglas Blackiston", "Dany S. Adams", "Guiscard Seebohm", "Barry Trimmer", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: KCNQ1, a six-transmembrane K+ channel, forms the "slow delayed rectifier" with its regulatory subunit KCNE1. Mutations in KCNQ cause cardiac long-QT arrhythmia and hearing loss in Jervell and Lange-Nielsen Syndromes. Previous research showed KCNQ1/KCNE1 involvement in Xenopus embryo left-right patterning. This study demonstrates that manipulating this channel's activity in Xenopus embryos leads to Xslug up-regulation and drastically increased melanocyte proliferation, shape change, and invasiveness. This research reveals a biophysical mechanism conferring a neoplastic-like phenotype on a specific embryonic stem cell subpopulation.
chunks.chunk_summary: KCNQ1/KCNE1 channel activity manipulation in Xenopus embryos affects melanocyte proliferation, shape, and invasiveness, potentially through Xslug up-regulation.
chunks.authors: ["Junji Morokuma", "Douglas Blackiston", "Dany S. Adams", "Guiscard Seebohm", "Barry Trimmer", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: KCNE1 misexpression in Xenopus embryos resulted in hyperpigmentation in 32% of larvae by stage 45. Other ion transporters did not cause this effect. Melanocyte number increased 2.1-fold, while total melanin content increased only 1.4-fold, indicating hyperpigmentation is due to increased cell number, not pigment content. This hyperproliferation was specific to melanocytes and did not disrupt overall morphogenesis or patterning.
chunks.chunk_summary: KCNE1 misexpression specifically increases melanocyte number, leading to hyperpigmentation in Xenopus embryos.
chunks.authors: ["Junji Morokuma", "Douglas Blackiston", "Dany S. Adams", "Guiscard Seebohm", "Barry Trimmer", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: KCNE1 modulates endogenous KCNQ1 channels. KCNQ1 contributes to resting membrane potential in Xenopus embryonic cells. KCNE1 coexpression reduces KCNQ1 currents, depolarizing embryonic cells. Chromanol 293B, a KCNQ1 blocker, also induces hyperpigmentation, supporting the hypothesis that KCNE1's effect is mediated by KCNQ1 inhibition. DiSBAC analysis confirmed that KCNE1 injection depolarizes embryonic cells, unlike control mRNA injection.
chunks.chunk_summary: KCNE1 inhibits KCNQ1 activity, leading to cell depolarization and hyperpigmentation.
chunks.authors: ["Junji Morokuma", "Douglas Blackiston", "Dany S. Adams", "Guiscard Seebohm", "Barry Trimmer", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: KCNE1 expression not only increases melanocyte number but also alters their location and morphology. Ectopic melanocytes become invasive, colonizing the neural tube, blood vessels, gut, and other organs. The KCNQ1 opener RL-3 caused hypopigmentation.  Immunohistochemistry with phosphorylated histone 3B showed increased mitotic cells in the melanocyte-rich region of KCNE1-injected larvae, indicating sustained hyperproliferation. While not forming discrete tumors, the melanocytes exhibit neoplastic-like characteristics: altered shape, hyperproliferation, and invasion of deep tissues.
chunks.chunk_summary: KCNE1 misexpression induces neoplastic-like characteristics in melanocytes, including hyperproliferation, altered morphology, and invasive behavior.
chunks.authors: ["Junji Morokuma", "Douglas Blackiston", "Dany S. Adams", "Guiscard Seebohm", "Barry Trimmer", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: KCNE1's effect on melanocytes is non-cell-autonomous. Injecting KCNE1 mRNA into various embryonic regions did not cause ectopic Xtrp-2 expression, indicating the hyperproliferation doesn't involve recruiting cells from other lineages. However, ectopic melanocytes were found in uninjected regions, likely due to migration from KCNE1-positive areas. Lineage tracing confirmed this non-cell-autonomous effect. KCNE1 induced ectopic Sox10 and Slug expression, regulators of neural crest and neoplastic cell behavior, without affecting other developmental markers or overall morphogenesis. This suggests KCNE1 selectively alters the spatial expression of key regulators of neural crest lineages.
chunks.chunk_summary: KCNE1's effect on melanocyte hyperproliferation and invasion is non-cell-autonomous, involving up-regulation of Sox10 and Slug.
chunks.authors: ["Junji Morokuma", "Douglas Blackiston", "Dany S. Adams", "Guiscard Seebohm", "Barry Trimmer", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Bioelectric signals play a role in morphogenesis and cell behavior.  This study identifies KCNQ/KCNE1 complexes as a key component of these biophysical signals. KCNE1 misexpression induces melanocyte overproliferation, while other cell types and overall development remain largely unaffected. Pharmacological manipulation of KCNQ1 confirms its role in melanocyte behavior control. The data suggest KCNE1 inhibits KCNQ1 activity, leading to cell depolarization and subsequent phenotypic changes. This provides molecular evidence for membrane potential's role in mitotic regulation.
chunks.chunk_summary: KCNQ/KCNE1 complexes are crucial for bioelectric signaling, with KCNE1 misexpression causing melanocyte overproliferation through KCNQ1 inhibition and cell depolarization.
chunks.authors: ["Junji Morokuma", "Douglas Blackiston", "Dany S. Adams", "Guiscard Seebohm", "Barry Trimmer", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: KCNE1's effect is primarily on melanocyte precursors, not involving cell fate conversion from other lineages.  The up-regulation of Sox10 and Slug by KCNE1 explains the observed phenotypes, providing a link between depolarization and transcriptional activation. The study proposes a model where KCNE1 reduces KCNQ1 function, depolarizing cells, and up-regulating Sox10 and Slug, leading to increased proliferation and invasiveness in melanocytes. This model highlights the role of bioelectric signals in controlling cell behavior through transcriptional regulation.
chunks.chunk_summary: KCNE1's effect on melanocytes involves up-regulation of Sox10 and Slug, linking depolarization to transcriptional activation and subsequent phenotypic changes.
chunks.authors: ["Junji Morokuma", "Douglas Blackiston", "Dany S. Adams", "Guiscard Seebohm", "Barry Trimmer", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: The findings have implications for cancer biology, as channelopathies are linked to neoplasm. Bioelectrical properties correlate with neoplastic potential, and ion channel function influences cell proliferation and invasiveness. While KCNE1 misexpression didn't induce tumors, it conferred neoplastic-like properties on melanocytes: Sox10 and Slug up-regulation, hyperproliferation, increased dendricity, and invasive behavior. This suggests that altered bioelectrical signals can contribute to neoplastic-like behavior in embryonic stem cells, potentially through misregulation of stem cell control mechanisms.
chunks.chunk_summary: KCNE1-induced changes in melanocyte behavior resemble neoplastic characteristics, suggesting a link between bioelectric signaling and cancer development.
chunks.authors: ["Junji Morokuma", "Douglas Blackiston", "Dany S. Adams", "Guiscard Seebohm", "Barry Trimmer", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: The KCNE1 phenotype may have broader significance due to the conserved nature of bioelectric mechanisms.  While KCNE1's role in mammalian neural crest function is untested, KCNQ1 up-regulation has been observed in mice with increased neural progenitor cells.  The conserved Sox10/Slug signaling pathway suggests KCNE1 overexpression should be investigated in human metaplasia and neural crest defects. Bioelectric events are crucial epigenetic processes, and this study links a clinically relevant ion channel protein to gene expression, cell number, shape, and location during development. Understanding bioelectric regulation of stem cells could reveal new markers and control points for biomedical intervention.
chunks.chunk_summary: The conserved nature of bioelectric mechanisms and the KCNE1 phenotype warrants further investigation into its role in mammalian neural crest function, human metaplasia, and neural crest defects.
chunks.authors: ["Junji Morokuma", "Douglas Blackiston", "Dany S. Adams", "Guiscard Seebohm", "Barry Trimmer", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: In situ hybridization and immunohistochemistry were performed to analyze gene expression and protein localization. Microinjection of mRNAs was used to manipulate gene expression in Xenopus embryos. Electrophysiology techniques were used to measure ion channel currents in Xenopus oocytes. DiSBAC2(3) dye was used to image membrane voltage patterns in embryos.
chunks.chunk_summary: The study employed various techniques including in situ hybridization, immunohistochemistry, microinjection, electrophysiology, and DiSBAC imaging to investigate the role of KCNQ1/KCNE1 in melanocyte development.
chunks.authors: ["Junji Morokuma", "Douglas Blackiston", "Dany S. Adams", "Guiscard Seebohm", "Barry Trimmer", "Michael Levin"]
